action_space.name: Establishing and Building the Therapeutic Alliance
action_space.description: Creating and nurturing a trusting, collaborative relationship between therapist and patient as the foundation for effective therapy.
action_space.goal: Foster trust, cooperation, and openness to facilitate productive therapeutic work.
action_space.states: Initial sessions, throughout therapy, especially when patient is disengaged, anxious, reluctant, or when ruptures or negative affect emerge.

micro_actions.name: Making Empathic Statements
micro_actions.description: The therapist verbalizes understanding and care, e.g., 'I care about you and value you.'
micro_actions.states: When building trust, responding to distress, discomfort, or alliance rupture.

micro_actions.name: Active and Reflective Listening
micro_actions.description: Therapist summarizes or reflects back the patient's thoughts or feelings to show understanding, e.g., 'You’re feeling overwhelmed right now.'
micro_actions.states: Whenever patient shares emotionally laden material, expresses confusion, or seems unheard.

micro_actions.name: Validating Patient Experience
micro_actions.description: Therapist acknowledges and normalizes the patient’s thoughts/emotions, e.g., 'It’s understandable that you feel this way.'
micro_actions.states: When patient expresses stigma, doubts, distress, shame, or embarrassment.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Agenda Setting
micro_actions.description: Therapist explicitly invites patient input into session structure, e.g., 'Is there something you would like to focus on today?'
micro_actions.states: At session openings, when shifting topics, or negotiating focus after resistance or disengagement.

micro_actions.name: Eliciting Feedback About the Session
micro_actions.description: Therapist invites feedback, e.g., 'Was there anything I said today that bothered you?'
micro_actions.states: Session endings, after introducing new interventions, and after observed patient discomfort/nonverbal cues.

action_space.name: Cognitive Conceptualization and Case Formulation
action_space.description: Formulating and continuously refining a personalized understanding of the patient's problems, beliefs, and history to guide interventions.
action_space.goal: Achieve an accurate problem understanding to inform treatment planning and increase therapist empathy.
action_space.states: At first contact and throughout therapy; when refining diagnosis, treatment approach, or addressing challenging presentations.

micro_actions.name: Eliciting Patient’s Account of Problems and History
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks open questions to clarify patient’s difficulties and significant life events, e.g., 'Can you tell me more about what brought you here?'
micro_actions.states: Initial sessions, when presenting new issues, or updating case formulation.

micro_actions.name: Checking Conceptualization Accuracy
micro_actions.description: Therapist summarizes their understanding and asks for patient feedback, e.g., 'Did I get that right? Is there anything I've missed?'
micro_actions.states: After proposing a working model, at conceptual updates, or following major revelations.

micro_actions.name: Hypothesis Testing and Validation
micro_actions.description: Therapist floats tentative hypotheses about links between events/thoughts/beliefs and requests confirmation or clarification.
micro_actions.states: When therapist presents a possible pattern or belief underlying patient’s problems.

action_space.name: Session Structuring and Agenda Setting
action_space.description: Organizing therapy sessions into predictable phases (check-in, agenda setting, homework review, problem discussion, summary, feedback) to ensure systematic and goal-focused work.
action_space.goal: Maintain session focus, maximize efficiency, reduce patient anxiety, and promote collaboration.
action_space.states: At the start of every session and whenever session focus or collaboration falters.

micro_actions.name: Greeting and Establishing Session Structure
micro_actions.description: Therapist introduces session plan, e.g., 'Today I’d like us to start with a check-in, then review homework, and discuss your main concern. Does that work for you?'
micro_actions.states: Session opening and when refocusing after tangents or disagreement.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Agenda Negotiation
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks the patient to contribute agenda items, e.g., 'What would you like to cover today?'
micro_actions.states: Session start and when patient’s priorities shift.

micro_actions.name: Gentle Interruption and Redirection
micro_actions.description: Therapist uses polite interruptions/coaching to maintain structure, e.g., 'Sorry to interrupt, but to keep us on track, can we focus on…'
micro_actions.states: When session topics drift or patient becomes tangential.

micro_actions.name: Explicit Summarization of Agenda
micro_actions.description: Therapist summarizes chosen items, e.g., 'So, our priorities today are…'
micro_actions.states: After agenda setting is complete.

action_space.name: Assessment and Identification of Problems
action_space.description: Eliciting and specifying the patient’s current problems, symptoms, emotional states, and relevant life events.
action_space.goal: Generate a clear list of prioritized issues to target in treatment.
action_space.states: Early sessions, when new problems arise, when emotion or behavior changes, or when selecting agenda items.

micro_actions.name: Direct Problem Inquiry
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks direct questions to clarify and specify problems, e.g., 'What seems to be troubling you most right now?'
micro_actions.states: Start of therapy, shift in symptoms, or patient reports distress.

micro_actions.name: Eliciting Emotional States and Updates
micro_actions.description: Therapist checks both current mood and changes, e.g., 'How have you been feeling since last session?'
micro_actions.states: Regular mood assessment, following reported life changes or troubling events.

micro_actions.name: Clarifying and Naming Problems Collaboratively
micro_actions.description: Therapist collaborates to label a problem, e.g., 'Should we call this “difficulty at work”?'
micro_actions.states: After problem description is ambiguous or fragmented.

action_space.name: Psychoeducation and Teaching the Cognitive Model
action_space.description: Educating the patient about CBT principles, the relationship between thoughts, emotions, and behaviors, and the rationale for treatment strategies.
action_space.goal: Increase patient understanding, buy-in, and ability to become their own therapist.
action_space.states: Early and mid-treatment, when introducing new concepts, explaining interventions, or normalizing symptoms.

micro_actions.name: Providing Rationale for CBT Techniques
micro_actions.description: Therapist explains purpose of interventions, e.g., 'We use these forms to help you understand your thinking patterns.'
micro_actions.states: When introducing new exercises or tools, especially if patient is skeptical or confused.

micro_actions.name: Explaining the Thought-Emotion-Behavior Link
micro_actions.description: Therapist utilizes metaphors/analogies, e.g., 'It’s like wearing dark glasses—the way you interpret things affects your mood.'
micro_actions.states: When clarifying the model, whenever patient expresses misunderstanding.

micro_actions.name: Checking Patient Understanding
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks patient to paraphrase/explain the cognitive model, e.g., 'Can you tell me in your own words how thoughts affect feelings?'
micro_actions.states: After presenting psychoeducation, before moving to application.

micro_actions.name: Normalizing Symptoms and Providing Hope
micro_actions.description: Therapist reassures patient that difficulties are common, e.g., 'Many people experience these kinds of thoughts.'
micro_actions.states: When patient expresses stigma, shame, or hopelessness.

action_space.name: Identification and Evaluation of Automatic Thoughts
action_space.description: Helping patients recognize, articulate, and critically assess their automatic thoughts; includes Socratic and guided questioning.
action_space.goal: Decrease distress by modifying dysfunctional thinking and increasing cognitive flexibility.
action_space.states: When patients are distressed, describe problematic situations, or show shifts in affect or maladaptive emotional responses.

micro_actions.name: Eliciting Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Therapist uses targeted questions such as 'What went through your mind when that happened?' or 'What thought popped up last night?'
micro_actions.states: Distress, emotional shift, discussing challenging situations, or when patient struggles to articulate thoughts.

micro_actions.name: Clarifying and Elaborating Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Therapist prompts for fuller or more specific thoughts, e.g., 'Can you put that thought into a complete sentence?'
micro_actions.states: Initial response is vague, confused, or telegraphic.

micro_actions.name: Guided Discovery and Socratic Questioning
micro_actions.description: Therapist challenges thoughts with open evidence-based questions, e.g., 'What evidence supports this thought? What evidence goes against it?'
micro_actions.states: When automatic thought is identified and needs evaluation.

micro_actions.name: Rating Belief Strength and Emotional Impact
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks for numerical/qualitative ratings, e.g., 'How much did you believe that thought at the time? And how strong is that belief now?'
micro_actions.states: After identifying an automatic thought, both pre- and post-intervention.

micro_actions.name: Linking Automatic Thoughts and Emotions
micro_actions.description: Therapist explicitly relates thoughts to feelings, e.g., 'What emotion did you feel when you had that thought?'
micro_actions.states: Clarifying cognitive-emotional link, teaching the model, or patient confuses thoughts/feelings.

action_space.name: Modifying Intermediate and Core Beliefs
action_space.description: Collaboratively identifying, evaluating, and restructuring deeper attitudes, assumptions, and core beliefs that underlie problems and automatic thoughts.
action_space.goal: Promote lasting cognitive and emotional change by altering maladaptive belief systems.
action_space.states: After groundwork with automatic thoughts; when beliefs are central to ongoing distress or dysfunction.

micro_actions.name: Uncovering Core Beliefs (Downward Arrow Technique)
micro_actions.description: Therapist uses Socratic questioning to probe deeper beliefs, e.g., 'What would it mean if that thought were true?'
micro_actions.states: When recurring or persistent dysfunctional thinking is present, or automatic thoughts point to underlying themes.

micro_actions.name: Evaluating Core Beliefs (Evidence Review)
micro_actions.description: Therapist queries for evidence, e.g., 'What evidence supports/contradicts this belief?'
micro_actions.states: After core belief is verbalized, in belief testing exercises or role play.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Belief Reframing
micro_actions.description: Therapist works with patient to develop more adaptive alternative beliefs, e.g., 'How might we rephrase this to be more balanced?'
micro_actions.states: Following evidence review, when modifying dysfunctional beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Tracking Belief Change
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks for ratings or summaries of belief strength, e.g., 'How strongly do you believe that now?'
micro_actions.states: Following intervention or at session closure.

action_space.name: Behavioral Activation and Skills Training
action_space.description: Planning and scheduling rewarding/mastery tasks, teaching behavioral coping skills, and using experiments to increase activity and test beliefs.
action_space.goal: Reduce avoidance, improve mood, and develop new adaptive skills.
action_space.states: When low mood, inactivity, or skill deficits are evident, or when cognitive methods alone are insufficient.

micro_actions.name: Scheduling and Reviewing Activities
micro_actions.description: Therapist explicitly assigns or reviews pleasurable/mastery tasks, e.g., 'Let’s choose an activity you can do this week.'
micro_actions.states: When working on increasing activation or practicing coping skills.

micro_actions.name: Proposing Behavioral Experiments
micro_actions.description: Therapist suggests activities to test beliefs/predictions, e.g., 'Would you be willing to try… to see what happens?'
micro_actions.states: When patient expresses doubts or predicts negative outcomes; when testing and challenging beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Positive Reinforcement and Encouragement
micro_actions.description: Therapist highlights achievements, e.g., 'What does it say about you that you completed that task?'
micro_actions.states: After completed activities, successful skill practice, or reported progress.

micro_actions.name: Troubleshooting and Problem-Solving Around Activities
micro_actions.description: Therapist discusses barriers and adapts plans, e.g., 'What was difficult about doing this? What could make it easier next time?'
micro_actions.states: When patient struggles, fails to complete activities, or expresses reluctance.

action_space.name: Homework Assignment, Review, and Troubleshooting
action_space.description: Collaboratively setting, reviewing, and adjusting homework tasks to reinforce session learning, facilitate skill generalization, and monitor adherence.
action_space.goal: Promote progress between sessions and develop self-therapy skills.
action_space.states: Every session end and review; when non-adherence or homework difficulties occur.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Homework Planning
micro_actions.description: Therapist reviews options, seeks agreement, and clarifies, e.g., 'What do you think about doing this as homework?'
micro_actions.states: Session close, after practicing a new technique, or at homework review.

micro_actions.name: Troubleshooting Obstacles
micro_actions.description: Therapist elicits and solves barriers, e.g., 'What might get in the way of finishing the assignment? How could you handle that?'
micro_actions.states: Patient shows avoidance, reluctance, or prior incomplete assignments.

micro_actions.name: Normalizing Setbacks and Reinforcing Homework as a Learning Process
micro_actions.description: Therapist assures patient, e.g., 'Homework is a no-lose proposition; it’s fine if things don’t go perfectly.'
micro_actions.states: Patient expresses frustration, self-criticism, or anxiety around homework.

micro_actions.name: Reviewing Homework Assignments Stepwise
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks patient to walk through what they did, challenges, thoughts, and outcomes, e.g., 'Could you tell me how you completed the assignment?'
micro_actions.states: Start of each session, and when discussing previous week’s activities.

action_space.name: Facilitation of Relapse Prevention and Termination
action_space.description: Preparing patients for therapy termination and future setbacks; teaching coping and self-management skills for long-term independence.
action_space.goal: Reduce risk of relapse and empower patients to maintain gains post-therapy.
action_space.states: As symptoms remit, during final sessions, and as a recurring theme for long-term planning.

micro_actions.name: Expectation Setting for Setbacks
micro_actions.description: Therapist normalizes setbacks and outlines plans, e.g., 'Everyone experiences setbacks—what might you do if that happens?'
micro_actions.states: Late stage, booster, or termination-preparation sessions.

micro_actions.name: Encouraging Review and Use of CBT Tools
micro_actions.description: Therapist prompts summary and future planning, e.g., 'Let’s list the strategies you’ve found most helpful.'
micro_actions.states: Preparing for termination or reviewing progress.

micro_actions.name: Role-Playing Responses to Setbacks
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks patient to imagine or rehearse coping responses to future challenges.
micro_actions.states: When anticipating setbacks, discussing high-risk situations.

micro_actions.name: Assigning Coping Card/Homework for Maintenance
micro_actions.description: Therapist encourages creation of reminders, e.g., 'Would you like to make a coping card for future challenges?'
micro_actions.states: During relapse prevention planning and homework assignment.

action_space.name: Monitoring and Remediation of Session Difficulties
action_space.description: Identifying and addressing problems in therapy process (alliance ruptures, structure breakdowns, stuck points) by soliciting feedback and adapting strategies.
action_space.goal: Resolve obstacles to progress and ensure continued effectiveness of therapy.
action_space.states: When progress stalls, session outcomes are unsatisfactory, or barriers to collaboration/intervention arise.

micro_actions.name: Soliciting Direct Session Feedback
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks about negative reactions or confusion, e.g., 'Was there anything about the session you disliked or found unclear?'
micro_actions.states: When progress stalls, alliance rupture suspected, or after introducing new interventions.

micro_actions.name: Addressing Nonverbal and Indirect Cues
micro_actions.description: Therapist checks in after noticing disengagement or frustration, e.g., 'I noticed you seem a bit withdrawn—can you tell me what’s going on?'
micro_actions.states: Observing negative nonverbal behavior or emotional shift.

micro_actions.name: Clarifying Rationale and Adapting Strategies
micro_actions.description: Therapist explains session structure and invites negotiation, e.g., 'Would a different approach be more comfortable for you?'
micro_actions.states: After patient pushes back, expresses confusion, or session structure breaks down.

micro_actions.name: Explicit Request for Patient Summary
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks patient to summarize their understanding or feelings, e.g., 'Can you put in your own words what we discussed about this issue?'
micro_actions.states: When patient seems confused, skeptical, or session content is complex.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient's current emotional state, including subjective and objective shifts throughout the session. Guides intervention choice and session pacing.
Level of emotional distress the patient is experiencing, crucial for managing risk and choosing interventions.
Current intensity of clinical symptoms (e.g., depression, anxiety, suicidality), impacts safety and treatment focus.
Quality of collaboration, rapport, and trust between therapist and patient. Determines engagement and effectiveness.
Patient’s participation, effort, openness, and collaboration within the session, affects progress and homework completion.
Degree to which agenda items/problems/goals are addressed and completed during the session. Guides structuring and priority shifts.
Presence, clarity, specificity, and intensity of automatic thoughts identified and discussed in-session.

Conversation_states.Variable Name: Degree of Belief in Automatic Thoughts
Conversation_states.Description: How strongly patient believes identified automatic thoughts (both 'intellectual' and 'emotional/gut'). Guides restructuring efforts.
Presence and strength of distorted/dysfunctional thought patterns in-session.
Degree to which underlying schemas, core, or intermediate beliefs are activated or discussed.
Conviction in intermediate/core beliefs (intellectual and emotional). Affects re-framing strategies.
Occurrence of maladaptive patterns (e.g., avoidance, catastrophizing) hampering progress within session.
Frequency and quality of adaptive coping behaviors/skills used by patient.
Presence and severity of behaviors that maintain distress or interfere with session (e.g., avoidance, inactivity, distraction).
Signs of physical activation associated with emotional distress or cognitive changes (e.g., agitation, tears, tension).
Degree to which patient has executed assigned homework and behavioral experiments. Guides accountability and motivation.
Presence and intensity of practical or psychological obstacles impeding homework or self-therapy.
Patient’s explicit and implicit feedback regarding therapy process, interventions, and therapist (verbal and nonverbal). Guides in-session adjustments.
Patient’s ability and frequency of applying CBT skills (identifying, evaluating, restructuring thoughts, using worksheets).
Patient’s readiness, willingness, and confidence to engage in planned change/homework.
Degree to which patient is advancing toward agreed-upon behavioral and emotional goals.
Patient’s understanding, acceptance, and identification with the individualized therapeutic/cognitive model.
How well patient follows session structure (forms, agenda-setting, completion of updates/tasks).
Amount of session time remaining and utilization of resources relative to agenda and patient needs.

knowledge_graph.description: Root node representing the individual in CBT.
Patient's age, gender, cultural, educational, religious, vocational, and developmental background.
Current emotional, cognitive, behavioral, and physiological symptoms.
Psychiatric, medical, and five-axis DSM diagnostic history and updates.
Childhood and developmental experiences, trauma, and major historical data affecting beliefs and present problems.
Family structure, support systems, social environment, involvement/support of significant others.
Learning style, intellectual level, reading/writing abilities, personality features, perfectionism, avoidance tendencies, motivational barriers, strengths, and values.
Therapist's evolving model of patient's difficulties, including links between symptoms, beliefs, triggers, and historical events.
Deep-seated dysfunctional or adaptive beliefs about self, others, and the world, including strength ratings, origin stories, and maintenance history.
Rules, assumptions, attitudes, both positive and negative, connecting core beliefs to thoughts and actions.
Typical and recurrent automatic thoughts: themes, triggers, situations, cognitive distortions, cataloging, and emotional/behavioral responses.
Common cognitive errors, such as jumping to conclusions or negative predictions, filtering, or data discounting.
Patterns, triggers, intensity ratings, and emotion-labeling ability (vocabulary, differentiation, intervention effectiveness).
Activity/inactivity history, schedule adherence, mastery/pleasure ratings, avoidance patterns, decision-making styles.
Adaptive and maladaptive coping behaviors, including compensatory patterns, self-reinforcement, relaxation, mindfulness, and problem-solving abilities.
History/patterns of engagement, ruptures, repair attempts, collaboration quality, feedback, patient motivation, and recurring barriers.
Record of assignments, rationale, completion status, barriers, learning, preferred methods for structuring, and efficacy.
Skill acquisition, proficiency, use outside sessions, mastery of cognitive techniques, activity charts, worksheets, progress tracking.
Concrete treatment goals, milestones, benchmarks, personal goal lists, self-therapy and relapse prevention plans, pie chart analyses of attribution/life balance.
Objective symptom scores (like depression/anxiety), mood/activity records, setbacks, relapses, and progress over time.
History of medication use and adherence, relevant side effects.
Suicidality, substance use, acute/chronic risks, and ongoing risk management.
Record of techniques tried, interventions, behavioral experiments, role plays, their effectiveness and patient reactions.
Themes and emotional responses to typical mental images, avoidance of imagery, preferred techniques, and coping strategies rehearsed with imagery.
